text_image_relationship.layout_style: Page organized in a grid of six equal rectangular miniatures (two columns by three rows) separated by a continuous decorative border of interlocking crosses. Each row of scenes is preceded or followed by a line of caption text in Old French, written in a single column above or below the miniatures. Visual hierarchy is given to the enthroned Virgin scenes by placing them in the upper-left, lower-left, and lower-right compartments, balanced by narrative episodes in the other panels. Wide margins are filled uniformly with the geometric cross motif, framing the entire composition.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura semiquadrata, professional book hand with regular use of ligatures and abbreviations

color_scheme.color_usage: Blue reserved for the Virgin’s mantle and clerical gowns, red for princely and lay figures. Gold leaf highlights divine figures and architectural ornament. Alternating red and blue motifs in border create rhythm. Layered application with white highlights on faces, good preservation with minimal pigment loss.

content_theme.scene_description: The first panel (top left) shows a single kneeling noblewoman rendered in three-quarter profile, her hands clasped in prayer before the Virgin Mary seated on a high dais under a Gothic colonnade. The Virgin wears an ultramarine mantle over a vermilion tunic and holds the Child on her lap, whose drapery is highlighted with white strokes. The dais is draped with a patterned textile of alternating gold and blue squares, each punched with decorative dots. Two slender columns support trefoil arches decorated in burnished gold, framing a spandrel with punched ornament. The kneeling figure’s robe of iron-oxide brown with blue lining identifies her high status; her headdress is edged in gold. Depth is suggested only by slight overlap of figures and receding arches. A narrow caption bar in red and blue ink runs above and below the scene, linking text and image. The white background emphasizes the flatness of the composition, while gilt elements draw the eye to the divine presence. The visual weight centers on the throne, balanced by the bowed figure at left, creating a focused devotional tableau.

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This mid-13th-century Old French hagiographic cycle was likely produced in a northern French workshop, perhaps in the Paris region, reflecting the vernacular turn in devotional manuscripts of the later Middle Ages. The grid-based narrative format, with six equal compartments framed by an interlocking cross motif, underscores the didactic aim: to guide the viewer through a sequence of miraculous intercessions. The repeated depiction of the enthroned Virgin Mary and Child in three panels demonstrates both the devotional focus and the hierarchical scaling typical of Gothic iconography. Technical execution—fine quill-pen underdrawing visible under UV, layered pigments, and raised gesso supporting burnished gold leaf—speaks to a professional atelier familiar with high-quality book production. The interplay of red and blue with gold leaf adheres to symbolic conventions (blue for the Virgin, gold for the divine realm) while the shallow spatial treatment reveals continuity with earlier manuscript traditions rather than emerging linear perspective. Comparatively, the vivid color palette and precise line work align this manuscript with other vernacular miracle books of the Île-de-France, though its Old French captions suggest a lay, rather than strictly monastic, audience. Overall, the codex balances conservative iconographic types with the innovative lay devotion practices of the 13th century, bridging liturgical function and personal piety.
